tossups.question: The narrator of a prose sketch drops these objects on the title “Bad Glazier.” In a collection titled for these objects, voices sing to “you who wish to eat” these objects in a poem to a child “fond of maps and engravings.” A collection titled for these objects features a figure “who, like the stab of a knife, / Entered my plaintive heart.” A “homesick” bird appears in a collection titled for these objects in a poem beginning (*) “Andromache, I think of you!” An “impeccable poet” receives these “unhealthy” objects in a collection that contains “The Swan” and later addresses the “hypocrite reader.” That collection titled for these objects contains “Parisian Scenes” and “Spleen and Ideal.” For 10 points, name these objects that title a poetry collection by Charles Baudelaire.
tossups.answer: flowers [accept fleurs; accept lotus flower; accept flower pot; accept The Flowers of Evil or Les Fleurs du Mal; prompt on pot by asking, “What was in the pot?”]

tossups.question: Josef Prusa improved upon a pioneering device for this technique nicknamed the “Mendel.” The University of Bath’s RepRap project centers on this technique; that project uses polylactic acid as an environmentally friendly way to create tools used for this technique. Stereolithography is a form of this technique in which a UV laser is focused onto a vat of photopolymer resin to initiate cross-linking. “Slicing” creates a G-code from (*) STL files in a common data preparation method in this technique. Ultimaker manufactures devices used in this technique, and designs for this technique are created using CAD and shared between users on Thingiverse. For 10 points, name this technique in which plastic is heated and extruded in layers to create an object.
tossups.answer: 3D printing [or additive manufacturing; prompt on printing or manufacturing; prompt on fused filament fabrication or FFF or fused deposition method or FDM by asking, “What broader technique is that part of?”]

tossups.question: In a movement depicting one of these events, a melody that begins with a yearning ascending major ninth reprises a preceding aria by the protagonist of one opera. Meredith Oakes modified the source text in the libretto of a Thomas Adès (“ADD-ess”) opera whose overture depicts one of these events. A passacaglia and musical depictions of “Dawn,” “Sunday Morning,” “Moonlight,” and one of these events facilitate (*) scene changes in one opera. After one of these events, the aria “Now the Great Bear and the Pleiades” is sung in a pub by that opera’s title character. One of these events excerpted in the last of Benjamin Britten’s “Four Sea Interludes” quotes Peter Grimes’s aria “What Harbour Shelters Peace.” For 10 points, name these events, one of which drives visitors to Prospero’s island in operatic adaptations of a play by Shakespeare.
tossups.answer: storms [or tempests] (The first line refers to the “Storm” interlude, which reprises Grimes’s “What Harbour Shelters Peace;” Oakes’s libretto modifies classic lines like “Full Fathom Five” from The Tempest.)

tossups.question: Édith Thomas discusses Élisabeth Dmitrieff’s founding, during this event, of an organization to valorize female labor in The Women Incendiaries. Female participants in this event, known as pétroleuses (“peh-troh-LUHZ”), allegedly set fire to buildings including resistance headquarters in the Hôtel de Ville. While being deported to New Caledonia in the aftermath of this event, Nathalie Lemel befriended an anarchist later immortalized as the (*) “Red Virgin,” Louise Michel. Archbishop Georges Darboy was executed over a failed prisoner exchange for Louis Blanqui during this event. The execution of dissidents on a wall in the Père Lachaise Cemetery suppressed this event on the final day of the Bloody Week. For 10 points, name this short-lived socialist government ousted by Adolph Thiers’s French Third Republic in 1871.
tossups.answer: Paris Commune [or Commune de Paris]

tossups.question: ANSWER: Paris Commune [or Commune de Paris] <GP, European History> 5. Note to moderator: read answerline carefully. In the Vimalakīrti Sūtra, a goddess modifies this thing belonging to Sariputra to chastise him after he assumes its inferiority in her. Through meditation, these things can be transformed into five radiant lights in a Tibetan “rainbow” version of them. Sambogha and Nirmāṇa examples of these things derive from the “true” one of these things named for dharma. It’s not the self, but in the Heart Sutra, Avalokiteśvara (“uh-vuh-lo-kih-TAYSH-vuh-ruh”) explains that this thing is (*) emptiness and emptiness is this thing. Buddhas have three of these things according to Trikāya doctrine. A set of meditations on death considers these things “swollen, blue, and festering” in charnel grounds. Contemplation of corpses emphasizes the impermanence of these things. For 10 points, consciousness arises from the interaction of the mind and what physical thing?
tossups.answer: body [accept rainbow body; accept kāya or samboghakāya or nirmanakāya or rūpakāya or dharmakāya or Trikāya until read; accept physical form; accept svarūpa; accept corpses or skeletons before mention; prompt on sex or appearance by asking, “What broader physical entity is that a part of?;”] (The corpse meditation quote is from the Satipatthana Sutta.)

tossups.question: Thomas Borstelmann examines Dean Acheson and the Truman administration’s fixation with South African supplies of this resource in Apartheid’s Reluctant Uncle. A warning of “threats without borders” that abetted growing supplies of this resource on the black market formed the Nobel Peace Prize lecture of Mohamed ElBaradei. The publication of Joseph C. Wilson’s op-ed about this resource caused the leaking of the identity of (*) CIA officer Valerie Plame. That op-ed, “What I Didn’t Find in Africa,” challenged the Bush administration’s consensus on the purchase of Nigerien (“nee-JAIR-ree-en”) supplies of this resource by Saddam Hussein. The “yellowcake” form of this element comprised the “weapons of mass destruction” used to justify the Iraq War. For 10 points, name this element enriched by the Manhattan Project to create nuclear weapons.
tossups.answer: uranium [accept U; prompt on yellowcake]

tossups.question: Australian chef David Thompson popularized “street food” from this country, often sold at the outdoor Chatuchak Market, to a British audience. Maria Guyomar de Pinha (“PEEN-yah”) introduced this country to numerous egg yolk-based Portuguese desserts, including a duck egg and coconut milk custard prepared in a square aluminum pan. The Monkey Buffet Festival in this country intentionally feeds thousands of crab-eating macaques in (*) Lopburi. An iced milk tea from this country is dyed a characteristic orange color. A noodle dish flavored with fish sauce, palm sugar, and tamarind and served with lime, bean sprouts, and chopped peanuts is named for this country, whose cuisine includes massaman curry and tom yum. For 10 points, name this Southeast Asian country with capital at Bangkok.
tossups.answer: Thailand [or Kingdom of Thailand or Prathet Thai or Mueang Thai or Ratcha Anachak Thai]

tossups.question: Composer and type of piece required. A polka in the ninth of these non-symphonic pieces includes a C-sharp ostinato inspired by the galop from William Tell. The first of these pieces to be written as a five-movement cycle features subtitles such as “Calm unawareness of the future cataclysm” that evoke a war story. A scherzo in one of these pieces was likely intended as a suicide note retrospective with quotes of pieces such as its composer’s E-flat major (*) cello concerto. An ensemble named for Alexander Borodin previewed these pieces for its composer, including one written while he was scoring the film Five Days, Five Nights in Dresden. That piece dedicated “to the victims of Fascism and War” opens with somber statements of the cryptomotif “D, E-flat, C, B.” For 10 points, name these pieces by the composer of the Leningrad Symphony for two violins, viola, and cello.
tossups.answer: string quartets by Dmitri Shostakovich [prompt on partial answer] (The quartets clued are Shostakovich’s ninth, third, and eighth quartets, respectively; the Borodin quartet previewed the quartets for Shostakovich before they were premiered, while the Beethoven Quartet usually premiered them.)

tossups.question: One character in this play recalls turning around while walking on a deserted road in a speech that ends with the exclamation “I’m no Judas!” Two characters in this play pretend to be surrounded by a flock of butterflies while reenacting a driving game that they played in a ruined Chevy. This play begins with a character routinely preparing a footbath at the sound of an (*) alarm clock. This play’s central characters roleplay as a rich man and a peanut vendor while buying a suit in a scene that culminates in one calling the other a “swartgat.” In this play’s final scene, its characters attack each other in their shack in Port Elizabeth upon learning that their pen pal Ethel Lange is engaged. For 10 points, the differently-skinned brothers Morris and Zachariah appear in what play by Athol Fugard?
tossups.answer: Blood Knot

tossups.question: Two conflicting explanations for the evolutionary origins of these structures are termed “inside out” and “outside in.” Mounting evidence suggests that these structures evolved from the dermal spikes responsible for sharkskin’s sandpaper-like texture. S. mutans is associated with the most common condition affecting these structures. These structures drift mesially in order to maintain (*) occlusion. Recent work suggests that bone remodeling may “lift” these structures through the alveolar bone, as opposed to force generated by the periodontal ligament causing their eruption. Diphyodonts like humans go through two sets of these structures. These structures’ innervated pulp chambers are covered by a hard hydroxyapatite matrix. For 10 points, name these enamel-covered structures that come in molar and incisor varieties.
tossups.answer: teeth [accept tooth]

tossups.question: In a story of these people, an evil being can be defeated by filling its skin with salt while it rides victims at night. A plant used in a religion of these people is named for John the Conqueror. To ward off the boo hag, these people originated the practice of painting houses “haint blue.” In a toast of these people, a monkey tricks a lion into fighting an elephant; that narrative is cited as an example of (*) “signifying” by Henry Louis Gates, Jr. One author collected folktales of these people in Of Mules and Men. These people told trickster stories about Br’er Rabbit. A steel-driving man of this ethnicity claims, “Hammer’s going to be the death of me.” That hero, John Henry, dies in a race against a steam drill. For 10 points, name these people whose stories from the Southern United States were studied by Zora Neale Hurston.
tossups.answer: African Americans [or Black Americans; accept Gullah; prompt on formerly enslaved people or Black slaves or African slaves before “ethnicity”; do not accept or prompt on “Africans” or specific African peoples] (The second line refers to Hoodoo.)

tossups.question: In a book titled for these entities, Partha Chatterjee criticizes the universalization of Western “modular” forms of one ideology. After ethnicity and class, these entities form the basis of the third paradigm of race that Omi and Winant reject in Racial Formation in the United States. One book argues that systems of “totalizing classification” like censuses and maps laid the basis for the creation of these entities, which originated with the New World’s (*) “creole pioneers.” These entities are a product of modernization according to Ernest Gellner. These entities arose from mass print media and the standardization of languages according to Benedict Anderson’s Imagined Communities. For 10 points, name these political communities of people with shared culture and history, which often form states.
tossups.answer: nations [or nation-states; accept Nationalist Thought and the Colonial World; prompt on countries; do not accept or prompt on “states”]

tossups.question: The author of this play discussed his decision to have a character instantaneously respond to a whistle in the second volume of his Theatrical Notebooks. A character in this play tells a bad joke about a slow-working tailor, then repeatedly asks for a sugarplum, after recalling a boating accident on Lake Como. This play’s set includes two high windows resembling eyes. A character throws away a three-legged toy dog and puts on his bloodstained “old stancher” (*) handkerchief at the end of this play, which opens with another character moving a stepladder back and forth. After losing their legs in a biking accident, an elderly couple in this play live inside dustbins. Nagg and Nell appear alongside the wheelchair-using Hamm and his servant Clov in, for 10 points, what play by Samuel Beckett?
tossups.answer: Endgame [or Fin de partie]

tossups.question: Anvils known as batánes were used by this country’s Sican culture to produce arsenic bronze. Excavations at a site in this country led Michael Mosely to posit a theory that fishing and not agriculture gave rise to civilization in this country. The site of Wari Kayan in this country contained pear-shaped “mummy bundles” that held people who had undergone forehead elongation as infants. In this country, John Reinhard and Miguel Zárate discovered the remains of Mummy Juanita, who was sacrificed as part of the (*) capacocha ritual. This country’s settlements of Aspero and Caral-Supe were part of its Norte Chico civilization. A hummingbird and a spider are among the zoomorphic geoglyphs that make up this country’s Nazca Lines. For 10 points, name this country, the location of Machu Picchu.
tossups.answer: Peru [or Republic of Peru or República del Perú]

tossups.question: In polymers, this property can be modeled as variable-range hopping between adjacent chains. Nanocrystals of the CT complex TTF-TCNQ have this property, which is also possessed by the emeraldine salt form of polyaniline. Examples of transparent thin films with this property include indium tin oxide. Hückel molecular orbital theory predicts that polyacetylene has this property because its HOMO and LUMO meet at the (*) Fermi level. Because of the quantity being measured, the atomically-thin tip in scanning tunneling microscopy must have this property. This property is proportional to the carrier density and mobility. Doping silicon with phosphorus or boron improves this property, which is possessed by materials with zero band gap. For 10 points, metals have what property of allowing the flow of electric current?
tossups.answer: electrically conductive [accept word forms like conductivity or conducting; prompt on metallic by asking, “What electrical property do metals have?;” do not accept “thermal conductivity”]

tossups.question: This statue is flanked by two blanketed sculptures of black women in stilettos lying on the ground in a commentary on colonial violence from a 2021 exhibition at the Legion of Honor by Wangechi Mutu. The British Museum’s Ian Jenkins argued that this sculpture’s closed fist indicates mourning. The creator of this sculpture claimed that it performs an action with “every muscle.” A copy of this sculpture is at the entrance to a museum commemorating its artist in (*) Philadelphia. This sculpture presided top-center in a work that also features Three Shades gathered together and a passionately kissing couple. Originally titled The Poet, this sculpture depicts Dante above the Gates of Hell. For 10 points, name this Rodin sculpture of a man contemplatively resting his chin on his hand.
tossups.answer: The Thinker [or Le Penseur]

tossups.question: The intellectual founder of this project was abandoned by his business partner in the flour business and wrote essays advocating for this project from debtors’ prison. At the inauguration of this project, cannons positioned in earshot of each other progressively fired a cannonade that took three hours to return to the original firing location. Jesse Hawley outlined early plans for this project under the pseudonym “Hercules” in the first of a series of essays in the (*) Genesee Messenger. Martin Van Buren joined with a political rival to support this project, which was funded by the New York State Legislature. The packet boat Seneca Chief made the inaugural voyage through this project. For 10 points, name this brainchild of DeWitt Clinton, an artificial waterway connecting the Hudson River to a namesake Great Lake.
tossups.answer: construction of the Erie Canal

tossups.question: The Michelle Simmons group uses hydrogen-resist lithography to engineer these objects. When connected to a charge reservoir with a Josephson junction, a “single Cooper-pair box” acts as one of these objects. Red-detuned laser pulses couple electronic and vibrational transitions in the Cirac-Zoller implementation of a device acting on two trapped-ion examples of these objects. To be effective, collections of these objects must be able to be initialized with high (*) fidelity and have a universal family of unitary transformations. Points on Bloch spheres represent states of these two-level objects, which are written as superpositions of “ket one” and “ket zero.” C-NOT gates entangle two of these objects, making computing with them more efficient. For 10 points, identify these units of quantum information.
tossups.answer: qubits [or quantum bits; prompt on single-atom transistors]

tossups.question: In one novel by this author, the motto “Let the impulse dictate the logic” is the “gambling creed” of Max Stenner, who hosts a Super Bowl party before a global blackout. The psychic Adele T. is called to help find Gladys Treadwell and her brother in a novel by this author, who are later discovered in a shopping mall. In a novel by this author Manx sells Bobby Thompson’s (*) “Shot Heard Round the World” originally caught by Cotter Martin. Klara Sax has an affair with a teenager who becomes the waste management executive Nick Shay in a novel by this author. In a novel by this author, Babette hides her use of the experimental drug Dylar from her husband, a professor of Hitler studies. For 10 points, name this author of Underworld who created Jack Gladney in White Noise.
tossups.answer: Don DeLillo [or Donald Richard DeLillo]

tossups.question: This concept inspires the prefix of the title of an essay that uses examples of the plantation and the colony to show how it subjugates its opposite. Foucault explains biopower in a chapter from The History of Sexuality partly titled for the “right of” this concept, which inspired Achille Mbembe’s extension. Afro-pessimists borrow from Orlando Patterson to describe the ontology of blackness with the “social” form of this concept. A Philippa Foot thought experiment inspired an essay by Judith Jarvis Thomson that argues that (*) letting this process occur is morally distinct from causing it. In psychoanalysis, eros is opposed to the aggression of this process’s drive. Epicurus argues that this process cannot be harmful because we do not exist to experience it. For 10 points, what permanent process occurs at the end of one’s life?
tossups.answer: death [or dying; accept necropolitics; accept social death or civil death or the death drive; prompt on getting run over by a trolley]

bonuses.leadin: Caspar Röist and the Swiss Guard allowed Pope Clement VII, a member of this family, to escape to Castel Sant’Angelo during the 1527 Sack of Rome. For 10 points each:
answers: Medici [accept Giulio de’ Medici, Giovanni di Lorenzo de’ Medici, or Lorenzo de’ Medici]
parts: Name this Florentine family, whose patriarch Lorenzo the Magnificent ensured the election of his son as Pope Leo X.

Mutinous Habsburg soldiers sacked Rome during a conflict named for this organization. Pope Clement VII united France, England, Venice, Milan, and Florence into this 1526 alliance to expel Charles V from Italy.
With the signing of the Treaty of Madrid, Francis I both redressed his earlier capture by Charles V at this 1525 battle and allowed for his joining of the League of Cognac against his former captor.

bonuses.leadin: Note to moderator: Read each answerline carefully before reading the bonus aloud. Seams in the leg integuments of armored crickets enable them to use a projectile form of this defense mechanism, though it also runs the risk of attracting other, more cannibalistic crickets in the process. For 10 points each:
answers: reflex bleeding [or autohemorrhaging; accept descriptions of squirting blood or hemolymph]
playing dead [accept thanatosis; accept any clear-knowledge equivalent of faking death; prompt on animal hypnosis; prompt on tonic immobility]
exploding [or autothysis; or abdominal dehiscence; accept word forms like explosions; accept obvious synonyms like rupturing; prompt on suicide or self-destruction by asking, “In what manner?”]
parts: Name or describe this defense mechanism used by horned lizards to deter feline and canine predators. Horned lizards enact this process by increasing pressure in the sinus orbitalis.

Grass snakes combine reflex bleeding and akinesia in this other defense mechanism. Opossums perform this behavior by rolling onto their backs, lolling their tongues out, and defecating when confronted by a predator.

Some hymenopterans perform an altruistic defense mechanism wherein they perform this action to release a caustic secretion in defense of their colonies. Though not voluntarily, beached whale carcasses may also do this.

bonuses.leadin: One ending of this novel that claimed that the world “kills the very good and very gentle” and “will kill you too but there will be no special hurry” was published with 47 other alternate endings for this novel. For 10 points each:
answers: Hemingway code heroes [prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this Hemingway novel where World War I ambulance driver Frederic Henry falls in love with Catherine Barkley.
In the official ending of A Farewell to Arms, Frederic sees this phenomenon as he walks back to the hotel after Catherine’s death. This phenomenon is the last word in A Farewell to Arms.

Henry is considered one of these archetypal men. These Hemingway-specific characters are defined as “[men] who [live] correctly…in a world that is…always painful,” and they face the “nada” of existence with dignity despite common flaws like insomnia, alcoholism, or fear of the dark.

bonuses.leadin: Little Walter intermittently plays solos on this instrument throughout his song “My Babe.” For 10 points each:
answers: harmonica [or French harp or mouth organ]
trains [accept locomotives; accept “This Train” or “Take the ‘A’ Train”]
parts: Name this free-reed instrument. Little Walter largely coined the vocabulary of this handheld instrument, whose players slide it across their lips to direct air in and out of the many holes along its mouthpiece.

Little Walter based “My Babe” on a Sister Rosetta Tharpe song named for one of these things. Joya Sherrill’s lyrics to another standard named for one of these things quickly grew more popular than its original lyrics by Billy Strayhorn.

“My Babe” is composed in a style of blues named for this city, distinguished in part by the amplifiers that musicians like Little Walter used while playing on Maxwell Street. Chuck Berry absorbed influences from this city’s blues from Willie Dixon and Muddy Waters.

bonuses.leadin: Political commentators hope Edgar Lungu’s concession to Hakainde Hichilema following a 2021 general election in this country will set a precedent for democratic transitions of power in Africa. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country, ruled as a one-party state by Kenneth Kaunda for much of the post-independence period.

Beginning after the 2010 self-immolation of Mohamed Bouazizi, a Tunisian fruit vendor, this series of protests across North Africa offered hope for a democratic future. This series of protests resulted in the ouster of Muammar Gaddafi and Hosni Mubarak.

After the Arab Spring, the Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet worked to ensure a democratic future for the country. However, those efforts have been imperiled by this current president, who, in light of protests against his handling of COVID-19, dissolved parliament and dismissed the prime minister.

bonuses.leadin: This essay begins by describing “dangerous” and “embarrassing” forms of the title concept, suppositions which were contested by Richard E. Vatz. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Lloyd Bitzer essay, a mainstay of Intro to Communications syllabi, which lists exigence, audience, and constraints as the three conditions needed for the title concept to occur.

Bitzer cites the most classic examples of constraints in a rhetorical situation as Aristotle’s “artistic proofs,” which consist of ethos, logos, and this appeal, consisting of persuasion on emotional grounds.
Bitzer uses the example of this anthropologist’s description of Trobriand fishermen’s utterances. This anthropologist took anthropology “off the veranda” in pioneering the use of fieldwork.

bonuses.leadin: This physicist and Isabelle Stengers wrote the book Order Out of Chaos, a philosophical exploration of how organization often emerges in systems driven far from equilibrium. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Russian-Belgian physicist who won the 1977 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. He did pioneering work on dissipative systems and irreversibility, laying much of the foundation for modern non-equilibrium thermodynamics.

Prigogine and Stengers cite classic results like Boltzmann’s H-theorem to argue that time’s arrow exists, and is pointed in the direction of increase of this quantity as predicted by the second law of thermodynamics.

Boltzmann’s H-function has the form: f times this function of f, where f is the distribution function. The form of entropy most useful in information theory is the sum over all states of: p times this function of p.

bonuses.leadin: This poem’s author dreams that he had replaced the name on his sister’s headstone with his own name in Rachel Corbett’s book titled for a line from this poem about his relationship with Auguste Rodin. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poem that remarks, “we cannot know” the “legendary head” of an object “with eyes like ripening fruit.” Rachel Corbett’s book titled for a line from this poem is the semi-fictional biography You Must Change Your Life.

Corbett’s book also details Rainer Maria Rilke’s formative relationship with this female psychoanalyst, who had previously engaged in an intellectual relationship with Paul Rée and Friedrich Nietzsche.

You Must Change Your Life recounts two disastrous meetings between Rilke, Andreas-Salomé, and this author, who spent most of those meetings berating their writing. This author wrote Anna Karenina and War and Peace.

bonuses.leadin: Depictions of the Mayan lightning god K’awiil frequently include a jade celt (“selt”) embedded in his head, from which this substance emerges. For 10 points each:
answers: bloodletting [accept piercing of tongues; prompt on self-flagellation by asking, “To release what substance?”]
parts: Name this substance, which can act as a medium for communicating with gods. Mayans burned rubber to produce copious black quantities of this substance, summoning black rain clouds.

After collecting the product of this action, paper was burned to produce smoke in Mayan rituals. In a Yaxchilan lintel, a serpent appears to Lady Xoc as she performs this action, which was often facilitated with stingray spines.
These Mayan soothsayers could communicate with the gods in trances potentially induced with entheogens. A Jaguar example of these people titles a Mayan text documenting their rituals and history.

bonuses.leadin: These animals provided the basis of a practice known as furūsīyah popular in the Mamluk Sultanate. For 10 points each:
answers: Battle of Ain Jalut [or Battle of Ayn Jalut]
parts: Name these animals. In addition to providing veterinary advice, various furūsīyah treatises instruct how to hunt or play polo while riding these animals.

When adapting furūsīyah horsemanship from Abbasid traditions, the Mamluks emphasized military training to counter Mongol aggression, which they halted at this 1260 battle. Baibars assassinated Qutuz, declaring himself sultan, after this battle.

The practice of furūsīyah likely influenced the Book of Chivalry, written after Geoffroi de Charny’s participation in this Europe-based conflict. Jean Froissart discussed chivalry during this conflict in the Chronicles.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about many-valued logical systems and ancient thought, for 10 points each.
parts: This philosopher extensively employed catuṣkoṭi (“CHUH-toosh-koh-tee”) argumentation, in which a proposition can be true, false, neither true nor false, or both true and false. He used it to argue the doctrine that everything is empty, or sūnyatā.

Fuzzy logics, in which truth values can take any real value from 0 to 1, are often used to model predicates with this property. This concept is demonstrated by the sorites paradox, which asks at what point a shrinking heap of sand is no longer a heap.

Ancient philosophers of this religion developed a seven-valued logic where each predicate is some combination of true, false, and inexpressible. Adherents of this Indian religion practice ahimsa, or nonviolence.

bonuses.leadin: The creator of a controversial one of these designs claimed that it fell out of use because “the verbal people have one great advantage over the visual people, they can be heard.” For 10 points each:
answers: NYC subway maps [accept equivalents like maps of the New York City subway; prompt on subway maps]
Fluxus [accept Fluxus / Rhythmus] (Perez’s murals are at 18th Ave in Brooklyn, and Yoko Ono’s is at 72nd St.)
parts: Name this type of design. The one currently in use is created by Michael Hertz and John Tauranac, replacing an unpopular rectilinear version that did not show curved lines.
The current Helvetica and previous Akzidenz-Grotesk on NYC subway signs are both fonts of this type. Arial is another font of this type, which lacks additional lines at the ends of strokes.

The NYC subway’s many artworks include Emilio Perez’s abstract mosaics named for this movement. The words “Imagine Peace” appear in a subway mosaic by Yoko Ono, a member of this performance-oriented art movement.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Church of Scientology’s espionage programs in the US, for 10 points each.
answers: L. Ron Hubbard [or Lafayette Ronald Hubbard; prompt on LRH]
Operation Snow White [accept answers describing a project or program called Snow White]
parts: Scientology’s espionage programs were executed by a church branch called Guardian’s Office, led by the wife of this man. This science fiction author founded the Church of Scientology.
In this operation, the Guardian’s Office conducted one of the largest infiltrations of the US government in history. This operation sought to steal government documents related to church activity.
Operation Snow White was initiated after the church failed to receive this status. In 1970, the Supreme Court held that grants of this status do not violate the Establishment Clause.

bonuses.leadin: This author claimed that “the status of ‘native’ is a nervous condition” in his preface to Frantz Fanon’s The Wretched of the Earth. For 10 points each:
answers: Jean-Paul Sartre [or Jean-Paul Charles Aymard Sartre]
parts: Name this French writer and thinker. Garcin exclaims, “Hell is other people!” in this author’s play No Exit.
This Zimbabwean author alluded to Sartre’s preface in the title of her novel about Tambu’s time attending a missionary school and living with her uncle Babamukuru, Nervous Conditions.
Sartre’s essay “Black Orpheus” opens a collection of poetry by this Négritude author. This author of the collection Éthiopiques also served as the first president of Senegal.

bonuses.leadin: An axiom in Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory guarantees the existence of a set with this property. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this property. Georg Cantor realized that some sets with this property are bigger than others, and denoted the size of countable sets with this property with the symbol aleph-null. The size of a set with this property is greater than every whole number.

This conjecture states that two to the aleph-null equals aleph-one, the smallest infinity greater than aleph-null. Because of this, there is no set whose cardinality lies between that of the natural numbers and the real numbers.

Aleph-one can be thought of as the number of these relations on the naturals. A set with one of these relations has the property that every non-empty subset has a least element, and is isomorphic to an ordinal number.

bonuses.leadin: Claudia Jones established an annual Carnival in this city to celebrate immigration from the West Indies. For 10 points each:
answers: Conservative Party of the United Kingdom [or Tories]
parts: Name this city. Groups of white teenagers known as “Teddy Boys” assaulted immigrants to this city during the 1958 Notting Hill race riots.
During the Notting Hill race riots, the “Teddy Boys” targeted this cohort of West Indian immigrants, named for a vessel that arrived in London from Kingston in 1958.

Enoch Powell, a member of this party, criticized the Race Relations Act of 1968 in the “Rivers of Blood” speech. The 1981 Brixton race riot occurred during the Premiership of this party’s Margaret Thatcher.

bonuses.leadin: A love poem by James Joyce comparing himself to this figure claims that “for elegant and antique phrase, / dearest, my lips wax all too wise.” For 10 points each:
answers: Mithridates VI Eupator [or Mithridates the Great]
reading their bad poetry [accept answers like reciting in place of “reading”; accept synonyms or superlatives in place of “bad”]
parts: Name this figure. In another poem, this figure gathers “all the springs to birth / from the many-venomed earth” before a group pours “strychnine in [this figure’s] cup / and shook to see him drink it up.”
The story of Mithridates appears in the final stanza of “Terence, this is stupid stuff,” a poem from this A.E. Housman collection set in the title English county.

The narrator of “Terence, this is stupid stuff” notes that Terence actually succeeds in killing a cow by doing this action. The Vogons torture Arthur Dent by doing this action in The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy.

bonuses.leadin: These mixtures are frequently used as vapor degreaser solvents in the cleaning industry. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these mixtures whose vapor composition is identical to their liquid composition. These mixtures are separated via methods that take advantage of the fact that changing the pressure removes their key property.
Azeotropes cannot be separated with the simple form of this technique, which selectively evaporates and condenses compounds in order to separate them by boiling point.
Azeotropic distillations are aided by using one of these apparatuses, which collect water in their traps. In these apparatuses, a boiling flask is connected to an inclined side arm.

bonuses.leadin: Vasari claimed that Properzia de’ Rossi, having “an intellect both capricious and very adept,” chose to carve material derived from these objects, which she then set into silver in her Grassi Family Crest. For 10 points each:
answers: fruit [accept specific ones, like peaches, plums, cherries, etc] (Properzia de’Rossi carved fruit pits; Bellori criticized Caravaggio’s mixture of out of season fruit)
Bologna (The Fountain of Neptune was sculpted by Giambologna; the Caracci Brothers founded an academy in the Bolognese School style of art.)
parts: Name these objects. Fede Galizia was renowned for her paintings of these objects, often accompanied by flowers. Gian Pietro Bellori criticized Caravaggio’s inclusion of a variety of these objects in his Supper at Emmaus.
De’ Rossi used this material for a bas-relief of Potiphar’s wife grasping at an escaping Joseph. Michelangelo used a variant of this material mined from Carrara for his David.

De’ Rossi worked in this city, where the Caracci family founded one of the earliest Western art academies. The common name of the Mannerist, Flemish-born sculptor of the Rape of the Sabine Women was derived from the name of this city.

bonuses.leadin: A prospect theory study concluded that a boundedly rational individual cannot maximize this quantity after a sudden decrease in income, due to a corresponding increase in risk aversion. For 10 points each:
answers: indirect utility function [do not accept or prompt on "utility function"]
parts: Name this function that represents consumer value given a set of prices for goods and, unlike a related function, a budgetary constraint.
By Roy’s identity, this quantity for a good is the derivative of the indirect utility function with respect to that good. This quantity for a good generally decreases as price increases.
The second term in the Slutsky equation relates a change in ordinary demand to this effect, in which demand for a good increases based on a consumer's purchasing power.
